properties.Name: HydrocrackerUnit
properties.Description:
The Hydrocracker Unit uses hydrogen to upgrade heavier fractions into lighter, more valuable products.

A hydrocracking unit, or hydrocracker, takes gas oil, which is heavier and has a higher boiling range than distillate fuel oil, and cracks the heavy molecules into distillate and gasoline in the presence of hydrogen and a catalyst. The hydrocracker upgrades low-quality heavy gas oils from the atmospheric or vacuum distillation tower, the fluid catalytic cracker, and the coking units into high-quality, clean-burning jet fuel, diesel, and gasoline.

The process cracks the high-boiling, high molecular weight hydrocarbons into lower-boiling, lower molecular weight olefinic and aromatic hydrocarbons and then hydrogenates them. Any sulfur and nitrogen present in the hydrocracking feedstock are, to a large extent, also hydrogenated and form gaseous hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and ammonia (NH3) which are subsequently removed. The result is that the hydrocracking products are essentially free of sulfur and nitrogen impurities and consist mostly of paraffinic hydrocarbons.

Hydrogen is also used to control the temperature of the reactor-it is fed into the reactor at different points. This keeps the reactor temperature from cooling to the point that cracking will not occur and from rising too high as to jeopardize the safety of the operation.

There are 4 primary reactions:
Reaction 1: Addition of hydrogen to aromatics converts them into hydrogenated rings. These are then readily cracked using acid catalysts.
Reaction 2: Acid catalyst cracking opens paraffinic rings, breaks larger paraffins into smaller pieces and creates double bonds.
Reaction 3: Addition of hydrogen to olefinic double bonds to obtain paraffins.
Reaction 4: Isomerization of branched and straight-chain paraffins.

Note:
Many refiners do not have hydrocrackers, but as demand for middle distillates such as jet fuel, kerosene, and diesel increases both in the United States and around the world, refiners may find incentive to build them to increase distillate yield. In the emerging low-sulfur world, the hydrocracker often converts high-sulfur materials, which would end up in marine or boiler fuel, into low-sulfur fuels for vehicles and airplanes. A refinery's ability to upgrade low-value products into high-value products and convert high-sulfur material to low-sulfur material with a secondary unit like a hydrocracker plays a key role in determining its economic fate.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Component.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitManufacturerName
Columns.Description: The name of the hydrocracker unit manufacturer.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitModelNumber
Columns.Description: The hydrocracker unit model number.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitConstructionCompletedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the hydrocracker unit construction was completed.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitFirstOperationDate
Columns.Description: The first operation date of the hydrocracker unit.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitDesignGraphic
Columns.Description: The design graphic of the hydrocracker unit.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitHeightMeters
Columns.Description: The height of the hydrocracker unit in meters.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitLengthMeters
Columns.Description: The length of the hydrocracker unit in meters.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitWidthMeters
Columns.Description: The width of the hydrocracker unit in meters.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitAreaSquareMeters
Columns.Description: The area of the hydrocracker unit in square meters.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitDesignCapacityMmtpa
Columns.Description: The hydrocracker unit design capacity in million metric tons per annum.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitNumberOfReactors
Columns.Description: The number of hydrocracker unit reactors.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitCatalystOperatingCycleMonths
Columns.Description: The operating cycle of the catalysts in the hydrocracker unit.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitNumberOfHighPressureSeparators
Columns.Description: The number of separators in the hydrocracker unit.

Columns.Name: RecycleGasAmineTreatmentIndicator
Columns.Description: Hydrocracker utilizes an amine treatment gas recycler.

Columns.Name: BufferGasCompressorIndicator
Columns.Description: Hydrocracker integrates a buffer gas compressor.

Columns.Name: VacuumColumnIndicator
Columns.Description: Hydrocracker integrates a vacuum column.

Columns.Name: VacuumFurnaceIndicator
Columns.Description: Hydrocracker integrates a vacuum furnace.

Columns.Name: DigitalControlsIndicator
Columns.Description: Hydrocracker integrates digital controls.

Columns.Name: AnalyticReportingIndicator
Columns.Description: Hydrocracker integrates analytic reporting.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitConfigurationTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a hydrocracker unit configuration type.

Columns.Name: HeatExchangerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Component.

Columns.Name: HydrocrackerUnitNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the hydrocracker unit.

Properties.Description:
The Hydrocracker Unit uses hydrogen to upgrade heavier fractions into lighter, more valuable products.

A hydrocracking unit, or hydrocracker, takes gas oil, which is heavier and has a higher boiling range than distillate fuel oil, and cracks the heavy molecules into distillate and gasoline in the presence of hydrogen and a catalyst. The hydrocracker upgrades low-quality heavy gas oils from the atmospheric or vacuum distillation tower, the fluid catalytic cracker, and the coking units into high-quality, clean-burning jet fuel, diesel, and gasoline.

The process cracks the high-boiling, high molecular weight hydrocarbons into lower-boiling, lower molecular weight olefinic and aromatic hydrocarbons and then hydrogenates them. Any sulfur and nitrogen present in the hydrocracking feedstock are, to a large extent, also hydrogenated and form gaseous hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and ammonia (NH3) which are subsequently removed. The result is that the hydrocracking products are essentially free of sulfur and nitrogen impurities and consist mostly of paraffinic hydrocarbons.

Hydrogen is also used to control the temperature of the reactor-it is fed into the reactor at different points. This keeps the reactor temperature from cooling to the point that cracking will not occur and from rising too high as to jeopardize the safety of the operation.

There are 4 primary reactions:
Reaction 1: Addition of hydrogen to aromatics converts them into hydrogenated rings. These are then readily cracked using acid catalysts.
Reaction 2: Acid catalyst cracking opens paraffinic rings, breaks larger paraffins into smaller pieces and creates double bonds.
Reaction 3: Addition of hydrogen to olefinic double bonds to obtain paraffins.
Reaction 4: Isomerization of branched and straight-chain paraffins.

Note:
Many refiners do not have hydrocrackers, but as demand for middle distillates such as jet fuel, kerosene, and diesel increases both in the United States and around the world, refiners may find incentive to build them to increase distillate yield. In the emerging low-sulfur world, the hydrocracker often converts high-sulfur materials, which would end up in marine or boiler fuel, into low-sulfur fuels for vehicles and airplanes. A refinery's ability to upgrade low-value products into high-value products and convert high-sulfur material to low-sulfur material with a secondary unit like a hydrocracker plays a key role in determining its economic fate.
